input:
2. A 7-year-old girl was referred to neurology for evaluation of progressive muscle weakness and visual impairment. Her parents noted she had struggled with delayed motor skills since infancy and had recently begun to experience frequent falls and difficulty with balance. Ophthalmologic assessment revealed congenital cataracts, restricted eye movements, and retinal abnormalities. On neurological examination, she exhibited hypotonia, mild limb contractures, and dysarthria. Brain MRI demonstrated hypoplasia of the cerebellum and brainstem alongside abnormal white matter signal changes. A muscle biopsy showed abnormal glycosylation of α-dystroglycan, consistent with a dystroglycanopathy. Genetic analysis identified compound heterozygous mutations in the POMT2 gene confirming Muscle Eye Brain disease. The multidisciplinary team started interventions focusing on motor rehabilitation, visual support, and seizure monitoring.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient is a 7-year-old girl, so she may not be able to articulate complex feelings or reasons clearly. She might be feeling worried about her muscles, her eyes, or how she’s been falling. I should keep her explanation simple and emphasize any recent changes or concerns she might have.

ANSWER: I don’t feel right… I’ve been falling more and my eyes feel weird sometimes. My arms and legs feel really tired and I don’t know why.

input: 2. A 7-year-old girl was referred to neurology for evaluation of progressive muscle weakness and visual impairment. Her parents noted she had struggled with delayed motor skills since infancy and had recently begun to experience frequent falls and difficulty with balance. On neurological examination, she exhibited hypotonia, mild limb contractures, and dysarthria. Brain MRI demonstrated hypoplasia of the cerebellum and brainstem alongside abnormal white matter signal changes. Genetic analysis identified compound heterozygous mutations in the POMT2 gene confirming Muscle Eye Brain disease. The multidisciplinary team started interventions focusing on motor rehabilitation, visual support, and seizure monitoring.Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, how they've changed over time, and how they are affecting your daily activities?
output: Um, I think she’s had problems with moving and seeing for a long time, but it’s been getting worse recently. She falls more often now and seems more tired, and she struggles a lot with playing and running around like other kids.

Brain MRI demonstrated hypoplasia of the cerebellum and brainstem alongside abnormal white matter signal changes. The multidisciplinary team started interventions focusing on motor rehabilitation, visual support, and seizure monitoring.Can you tell me more about how your movement and vision problems have affected your daily life recently, and if there are any other changes or difficulties you've noticed?
output: Well, I fall sometimes even when I try not to, and my eyes feel funny, like I can't see straight and everything is a little blurry. It’s hard to do some things, and I get tired really fast.

input: 2. A 7-year-old girl was referred to neurology for evaluation of progressive muscle weakness and visual impairment. Her parents noted she had struggled with delayed motor skills since infancy and had recently begun to experience frequent falls and difficulty with balance. Genetic analysis identified compound heterozygous mutations in the POMT2 gene confirming Muscle Eye Brain disease. The multidisciplinary team started interventions focusing on motor rehabilitation, visual support, and seizure monitoring.Can you tell me more about how your symptoms—like your movement difficulties and vision problems—have impacted your everyday activities, and if there are particular things you've found especially challenging or new since they started?
output: Um, I guess I get tired really fast when I try to do things like play or walk around, and sometimes I can’t see things clearly, especially if they move a lot. I’ve fallen a few times more than before, and it makes me scared to move too fast or be anywhere with lots of people. I feel kind of tired and worried a lot.

input: 2. A 7-year-old girl was referred to neurology for evaluation of progressive muscle weakness and visual impairment. Her parents noted she had struggled with delayed motor skills since infancy and had recently begun to experience frequent falls and difficulty with balance. Ophthalmologic assessment revealed congenital cataracts, restricted eye movements, and retinal abnormalities. On neurological examination, she exhibited hypotonia, mild limb contractures, and dysarthria. Brain MRI demonstrated hypoplasia of the cerebellum and brainstem alongside abnormal white matter signal changes. A muscle biopsy showed abnormal glycosylation of α-dystroglycan, consistent with a dystroglycanopathy. Genetic analysis identified compound heterozygous mutations in the POMT2 gene confirming Muscle Eye Brain disease. The multidisciplinary team started interventions focusing on motor rehabilitation, visual support, and seizure monitoring.Has she experienced any episodes of sudden or transient visual loss, weakness, or numbness in her limbs? Has she noticed any other symptoms such as headaches, recent weight loss, or fever? Also, is there any family history of neurological, muscular, or autoimmune diseases?
output: Well, sometimes her eyes seem to get a bit more flickery, and she does get tired really easily, but I don’t know if it’s because she’s just tired or something else. She hasn’t really said she lost her vision suddenly or anything like that, and she doesn’t complain about being numb or weak in her arms or legs, as far as I know. No headaches or fevers that I’ve noticed, and no one in the family has anything like that, at least not that I know of.

The multidisciplinary team started interventions focusing on motor rehabilitation, visual support, and seizure monitoring.Does she experience any double vision or difficulty moving her eyes, such as trouble following objects or involuntary eye movements?
output: Um, yes, she often feels like the words or things she looks at aren’t quite clear, and sometimes her eyes don’t seem to move the way they’re supposed to. She gets confused when trying to follow moving stuff.

output: Um, there was this one time, I think, when everything looked weird for a little while, and it sort of went away pretty quick. I don’t really know if it was my eyes or something else, but it was kinda scary.

output: I think she does get kind of wobbly sometimes and falls more than usual, but I’m not sure if it’s just her losing balance or something else. She hasn’t really told me she feels numb or tingly, but maybe she gets a bit fussier or confused when she’s off-balance?

On neurological examination, she exhibited hypotonia, mild limb contractures, and dysarthria. Brain MRI demonstrated hypoplasia of the cerebellum and brainstem alongside abnormal white matter signal changes. A muscle biopsy showed abnormal glycosylation of α-dystroglycan, consistent with a dystroglycanopathy. Genetic analysis identified compound heterozygous mutations in the POMT2 gene confirming Muscle Eye Brain disease. The multidisciplinary team started interventions focusing on motor rehabilitation, visual support, and seizure monitoring.Has she noticed any particular triggers that worsen her eye symptoms or episodes—such as heat, exhaustion, or stress—and would she be willing to start additional therapies or undergo further testing to confirm the diagnosis and manage her symptoms effectively?
output: Um, sometimes my eyes feel weird when I get really tired or if I run around a lot. I don't know if it's the heat or anything like that. I guess I'm okay to try more treatments or tests if it might help, but I don't really understand all of it.
